title: Significant income drop
description: Wages dropped by $21.5k (-15%) vs Prior Year.
explanation: Bing Equipment W-2 dropped $22k ($82k → $60k); Tech Circle stable. Could be reduced hours, role change, or scan error.
rootCause: Bing W-2 shows $22k reduction with low scan confidence (72%). Verify against source document.
suggestedAction: Verify the W2 Bing wages amount ($60,000) against the source document. The scan confidence is low (72%). Confirm with the client whether the income reduction is expected.
whyItMatters: A 15% income drop is significant and could indicate missing income documents, data extraction errors, or unreported income. The IRS cross-references W-2 data, so any discrepancy will trigger a notice.
estimatedTaxImpact: ~$4,600 lower tax liability from the $20.7k wage drop (lower taxable income)

title: Potential missing document: Chase Bank 1099-INT
description: A 1099-INT from Chase Bank was present last year but not imported this year.
explanation: Chase 1099-INT ($1,200) was filed last year but not imported this year. If account is active, interest may be understated.
rootCause: Chase 1099-INT missing from import. Client may have closed account or document not yet uploaded.
suggestedAction: Contact the client to confirm if the Chase Bank account was closed or if the 1099-INT was simply not uploaded yet.
whyItMatters: Missing income documents lead to underreported income. The IRS receives copies of all 1099s and will issue a CP2000 notice for any unreported interest income, plus penalties and interest.
estimatedTaxImpact: ~$264 additional tax if $1,200 Chase interest is unreported (22% bracket)

title: Low scan confidence on W2-Bing.pdf
description: OCR confidence is 72% for the W2-Bing document. The wages field ($60,000) may not be accurately extracted.
explanation: W2-Bing OCR confidence is 72% on Box 1 (Wages). ~28% chance $60,000 is wrong.
rootCause: Low-resolution scan or photo. Verify wages against document image.
suggestedAction: Open the W2-Bing source document to verify the wages amount. Compare the extracted $60,000 against what's visible on the document image. If incorrect, edit the value in the source extraction panel.
whyItMatters: Inaccurate data extraction leads to incorrect tax calculations. If the wages are wrong, federal withholding, Social Security, and Medicare calculations will also be wrong, potentially resulting in an incorrect refund or balance due.
estimatedTaxImpact: Could vary $500–$5,000+ depending on correct wages; low OCR confidence on W2-Bing

title: Potential address discrepancy
description: Address on W2-Bing (331 Easy Street) may differ from the return address (333 Easy Street).
explanation: W2-Bing shows 331 Easy Street; return has 333. Likely OCR error or address change.
rootCause: Address mismatch can trigger IRS letters. Verify with client.
suggestedAction: Cross-reference the address against the W-2 addresses and prior year return. Confirm with the client that 333 Easy Street, Middlefield, CA 98756 is their current address.
whyItMatters: Address typos and mismatches are one of the most common causes of IRS letters and delayed refunds. A simple verification step can prevent weeks of client frustration.
estimatedTaxImpact: No tax change; may delay refund if IRS flags address mismatch

title: Under-withholding: safe harbor risk
description: Total federal withholding ($19,800) is only 82% of total tax liability ($24,186). Client may owe an underpayment penalty.
explanation: Withholding ($19,800) is 82% of tax ($24,186). Below 90% safe harbor. ~$350 penalty may apply.
rootCause: Shortfall of $4,386. Neither 90% current-year nor 100% prior-year threshold met.
suggestedAction: Inform the client about the $4,386 balance due and potential underpayment penalty. Recommend adjusting W-4 withholdings for the current year to prevent recurrence. Consider if estimated tax payments were made but not yet documented.
whyItMatters: The IRS charges an underpayment penalty (currently ~8% annualized) when taxpayers don't meet safe harbor withholding thresholds. Flagging this early allows the preparer to advise the client and check for any estimated payments that may offset the shortfall.
estimatedTaxImpact: ~$350 underpayment penalty + $4,386 balance due (withholding 82% of tax, below 90% safe harbor)

estimatedPenalty.calculation: Shortfall of $4,386 × ~8% annualized rate, prorated across quarters

title: Charitable giving high relative to income — IRS audit trigger
description: Charitable deductions ($8,000) are 6.2% of AGI. Typical range is 3–5%. High ratios trigger IRS scrutiny.
explanation: Schedule A charitable of $8,000 vs. AGI $129,933 = 6.2%. IRS flags ratios above ~5% as potential overstatement. Verify documentation even if legitimate.
rootCause: Charitable-to-AGI ratio (6.2%) exceeds typical 3–5% range; disproportionate deductions are a known audit trigger.
suggestedAction: Obtain receipts and written acknowledgments for all charitable contributions. Confirm the $8,000 is accurate and properly documented. High ratios require strong substantiation.
whyItMatters: Charitable deductions disproportionate to income are one of the top IRS audit triggers. Even legitimate deductions should be well-documented with receipts and acknowledgment letters.
estimatedTaxImpact: Audit risk if unsubstantiated; potential disallowance of excess charitable deduction if documentation is insufficient

title: Multi-job withholding gap
description: Taxpayer has two W-2 jobs. Combined withholding may not account for higher marginal bracket from total income.
explanation: Two jobs withhold at lower brackets. Combined $124K pushes into higher bracket — systematic under-withholding.
rootCause: Each employer withholds as if sole income. Recommend W-4 Step 2 'Two jobs' or Tax Withholding Estimator.
suggestedAction: Advise the client to submit updated W-4 forms to both employers, checking the 'Two jobs' box on Step 2, or use the IRS Tax Withholding Estimator to calculate the additional withholding needed.
whyItMatters: Multi-job withholding gaps are one of the most common causes of surprise tax bills. Proactive W-4 adjustment prevents this from recurring next year.
estimatedTaxImpact: Drives the $4,386 balance due; two jobs withhold at lower brackets than combined income

title: Taxable interest increased 42%
description: Taxable interest rose from $3,200 to $4,535 (+42%). Verify this is consistent with the client's savings activity.
explanation: Interest up $1,335 (+42%). Likely higher rates; confirm no new accounts missing 1099-INT.
rootCause: $4,535 vs $3,200 prior year. Verify all interest sources documented.
suggestedAction: Confirm with the client whether the interest increase is from existing accounts (higher rates) or new accounts. If new accounts exist, ensure all 1099-INTs are collected.
whyItMatters: A 42% increase in interest income is notable. While likely explained by rate increases, it's worth confirming no additional interest income sources are missing.
estimatedTaxImpact: ~$295 additional tax from $1,335 interest increase (22% bracket)
